messages: e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (21:23): ORA-00054: resource busy and acquire with NOWAIT specified
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (21:23): how can I find & kill this session ?
fb02627b715a95bb15f9a9f7623a4a70 (21:42): trying to recover from control file till cancel
fb02627b715a95bb15f9a9f7623a4a70 (21:42): ORA-01251: Unknown File Header Version read for file number 1
fb02627b715a95bb15f9a9f7623a4a70 (22:01): ok it doesnt like any of my files
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:12): how can I convince developers that XE is garbage compared to the Enterprise DB ?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:15): and is your reference to "Enterprise DB" a reference to Oracle Enterprise Edition or the postgresql based database EnterpriseDB
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:15): Oracle Enterprise Edition, a ful blown 10.2.02 DB
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:15): what features in EE do you need?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:16): but if your developers don't use those features anyway?
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:16): the problem is the crap default tablespace
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:17): and they do need to do work in the metadata repositories
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:18): we call it the "Fisher Price Database"

443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:18): what im saying is that Oracle XE is not crap by far.. it has it's place.. but if you think you're actually going to use any SE/EE features or goign to grow beyond 4Gb data, or if you need more than 1 cpu and 1 gb ram
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:18): from what im hearing here the only reason you don't like XE is snobbery?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:19): i don't think BPEL or OID are arguments you can use
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:19): seeing the lowest hardwar spec is 2gb and the servers have more than 2 cpus
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:19): I can't use XE as a metadata repository
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:20): besides the db doesn't pass prereqs testing
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:20): Ultra Search and stuff like that
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:20): for use as a Metadata Repository
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:21): that argument i can understand, if you run a mission critical app you probably want database support
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:21): do you consider I need the release to go out by weeks end, mission critical ?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:22): what happens if you don't get a release out?
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:22): we have to schedule deployment time.  If the release misses the time, it could be a month or longer before the next chance arises

443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:23): i still don't know if that is mission critical, you tell me.. if it is and you can afford the licensing costs.. fine then you should definatly go for at least SE One
7e5c4309185069f0f0603b1973fdf7af (22:24): The contract I am working on has a software agreement where we get the DB free
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:24): then if you and management think it should be used.. then use it
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:25): since it seems like a zero cost
fb02627b715a95bb15f9a9f7623a4a70 (22:32): did a SELECT * FROM V$RECOVER_FILE; and like 30 of them show
fb02627b715a95bb15f9a9f7623a4a70 (22:32): all of them are listed as corrupt and there are like 4 of them that are listed as not found
fb02627b715a95bb15f9a9f7623a4a70 (22:33): could it be that i am putting the files in the wrong place?
98539571174600c9ea1e6ab113289c96 (23:00): could you tell me how can I realise lef join in oracle ?
98539571174600c9ea1e6ab113289c96 (23:12): it seems that this is INNER JOIN, but i need LEFT
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (23:14): FROM person p, title t
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (23:15): place the join on the other side?
16c7690c946b4701dc783ac70f549cfb (23:24): what does this SQL cmd, select count(*) from control where customer_data_id = 161; , tells you?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (23:25): how many customers with data_id 161 you have
98539571174600c9ea1e6ab113289c96 (23:28): from (select control_id, content from control_data where customer_data_id = 161  ) cdata
98539571174600c9ea1e6ab113289c96 (23:28): I don't know why oracle treat it this way
98539571174600c9ea1e6ab113289c96 (23:28): mysql in this case is more easier :)
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (23:28): oracle 9i and up has the same join syntax
27fa0f96dfc03bb1f2bebd6fee16f716 (23:37): mysql hasnt had joins long enough to have a non standard syntax for them :p
